title: Four Perspectives on the AI Knowledge Work Thesis

perspectives.name: Enterprise Executive
perspectives.initial_position: My first reaction is defensive arrogance masking real concern. We've weathered every 'consulting is dead' prediction for decades. But this feels different. The speed of capability improvement and cost collapse in AI isn't following our familiar playbook.
key_threats: Margin compression on commodity expertise deliveryâ€”$500/hour work becomes $50/hour
AI leverage ratio inverts our scale advantageâ€”200 analysts become 3-person AI team
Knowledge Programmers bypass us entirelyâ€”clients can amplify their own people 10x
key_moves: Aggressively acquire AI-native boutiques at 3-5x revenue multiples
Restructure pricing toward outcomes, away from billable hours
Create separate P&L for AI-augmented services, insulated from legacy overhead
blind_spots: Underestimating how fast clients expect AI-speed delivery
Overconfident that 'strategic work' stays immune to AI
perspectives.revised_position: 70% convinced thesis is correct. The real risk isn't that consulting disappearsâ€”it's that we become structurally disadvantaged against AI-native competitors. Window to transform is 2-3 years. After that, we're defending market share, not capturing value.

perspectives.name: Solo Entrepreneur
perspectives.initial_position: This thesis is why I left. The big firms are dinosaurs watching the meteor. As a solo operator with AI tools, I can deliver what used to require a team of 10. My overhead is near zero, my speed is 10x, and I don't need anyone's permission to adopt new tools.
key_threats: Zero-to-one speed on adoptionâ€”no procurement, no committees, no legacy systems
Can price 50% below big firms while making 3x their margins
Personal brand + AI leverage = unlimited scalability without hiring
key_moves: Build agent systems for my core deliverables in Q1
Document everythingâ€”create 'playbooks' that become my competitive moat
Target the clients big firms ignore: too small for McKinsey, too complex for DIY
blind_spots: If AI democratizes my edge, every consultant becomes a competitor
Enterprise clients may still want 'big firm credibility' regardless of capability
I'm one personâ€”illness, burnout, or distraction kills the business
perspectives.revised_position: The window is real but narrowing. My advantage isn't just AIâ€”it's AI plus domain expertise plus speed of execution. I have 18-24 months before the big firms figure this out or AI-native startups flood the market. Move fast, build systems, establish reputation before the window closes.

perspectives.name: Hedge Fund PM
perspectives.initial_position: This thesis conflates productivity enhancement (real) with business model disruption (overstated). The 36-month timeline screams recency bias. Token cost decline is real but irrelevant if switching costs and compliance dynamics don't change. I'm more interested in who captures margins than who generates productivity.
key_threats: Management consulting (ACN): junior analyst leverage model breaks, 30-40% margin compression
Legal process outsourcing: document review commoditizes, 40-60% margin compression
Corporate training (2U, Udemy): loses to personalized AI tutoring
key_moves: Long VEEV + EVR: data moats and elite advisory pricing power
Short ACN vs Long PLTR: body shop model disruption spread trade
Long vertical SaaS with >70% gross margins and domain-specific data
blind_spots: Market underprices premium human services margin EXPANSION
VCs overpricing 'AI-native' startups without data moatsâ€”shakeout coming
perspectives.revised_position: Thesis directionally correct but off by 24-36 months on timing. The trade isn't 'AI winners vs laggards'â€”it's margin expansion in data-moated verticals vs margin compression in labor arbitrage models. The 10x variance accrues to individuals, not employers. That's a headwind for large-cap professional services.

perspectives.name: Private Equity Partner
perspectives.initial_position: This thesis inverts our traditional value creation playbook. I'm no longer buying talent density and optimizing processes. I'm buying distribution, relationships, and judgmentâ€”then injecting AI leverage to explode margins while reducing headcount.
key_threats: High-cost knowledge shops with commoditized outputâ€”margins compress to zero
Lifestyle businesses resisting systematizationâ€”no process = no AI leverage
Mid-market SaaS getting squeezed by AI-native point solutions
key_moves: Target professional services with strong brands but inefficient deliveryâ€”3x EBITDA potential
Roll-up regional firms with AI back-office: revenue flat, costs -40%, EBITDA triples
Day 1 operational playbook: AI fluency assessment, Knowledge Programmer hiring, fire resistors
blind_spots: AI transformation creates 2-3x multiple premium at exit
Do nothing = 30-50% multiple compression as buyers price in disruption risk
perspectives.revised_position: Deploy 40% of fund into AI-transformable knowledge businesses over next 18 months. Target companies with proprietary relationships, documentable complexity, and internal champions. The risk isn't that AI fails to deliver. The risk is moving too slowly and watching competitors eat our portfolio from below.

consensus: The transformation is real, not hypeâ€”all four perspectives agree on directional correctness
Timing is debated: 36 months vs 5-7 years, but all agree the window to act is NOW
Winners will be determined by AI leverage ratios, not traditional scale advantages
Knowledge Programmer role is the key unlockâ€”AI-fluent generalists win
disagreements: Timeline: Enterprise sees 2-3 years to transform; Hedge Fund sees 5-7 years for full disruption
Who wins: Entrepreneur sees individual opportunity; PE sees roll-up consolidation play
Market pricing: Hedge Fund thinks AI-native startups overvalued; PE aggressively deploying
synthesis.key_insight: The debate reveals a barbell outcome: elite human judgment becomes MORE valuable while commodity knowledge work races to zero. The middle gets squeezed hardest.
